_header: I am Mercury the mighty Flos Florum
Note:
Part of this poem occurs as part (ch. 36 seqq.) of the Liber
Patris Sapientiae, in Ashmole (1652)
XAshmole, Elias. Theatrum Chemicum Britannicum. London: J. Grimond, 1652, 194-209.

BodAsh1490.First Lines:
I am Marcury the mighti flos florumI am moste worthy of all
                    singularum…
BodAsh1490.Last Lines:
…All is done in howars .3.this may be called gods
                    pryvitie
BodAsh1490.Note: Second occurrence in MS; written as prose.

BodAsh1480.First Lines:
I am mercury that mightye flose flowerI am moste ryall and richiste
                    Singuler…
BodAsh1480.Last Lines:
…Seke it fourther as I haue soughtefor other of me you gett
                    right noughte

BodAsh1451.First Lines:
I am mercury the myghty flos florumI am moste Ryall and rychest of
                    singlorum…
BodAsh1451.Last Lines:
…Seke forthe folys as ye haue soughtFor in all other thynge ye
                    fynde hym nowght
BodAsh1451.Attributed Title:
A fragment of a tratise which (I here say) is called Sapientia
                        Patris (f. 62v); this title is according to Black’s
                    Ashmole Catalogue, in Dr. Dee’s hand)

BodeMus63.First Lines:
I am Mercury the myghtie fflos fflorummost riall and Richest aboue
                    all ore…
BodeMus63.Last Lines:
…and her calcination ys a thousand ffouldVnto all mettalls as
                    precious & swete as gold

CamTCC1119.First Lines:
I am Mercury the might flos florumI am most royall and
                    richest of all singulores…
CamTCC1119.Last Lines:
…Of thy desine then may it not missAnd also of heauen that
                    sweet bliss. Finis

BLSl1092.First Lines:
I am {Mercury} the mightye flos florumI am moste owrthyest of all
                    singulorum…
BLSl1092.Last Lines:
…moother & lotrix of all wourckyngeIn my dawghter theare
                    been hydd cc

YaleBeiOsfa16.First Lines:
I am {mercury} the hyghty flos florum aloneI am most richest &
                    ryall of althyngfor of gold & siluer I am gouernore…
YaleBeiOsfa16.Last Lines:
…sek furth foles as ye haue soughtfor in all other thynges ye
                    fynd right noght
YaleBeiOsfa16.Note:
Begins with imperfect rhymes, but develops into couplets; pages numbered
                    41, 42; written by a hand of the sixteenth century; ends
                    ‘Explicit’.
